entry.title: Modernizing ImpactJS - Part 1 : The Modules
entry.content:
If you were interested in making games for the web between 2010 and 2014, chances are that you landed at least once on the ImpactJS front page. This was (and still is) a really great engine. It packs a map editor, an entity system, basic physics and collisions...

I still like to prototype a bit with ImpactJS every once in a while. You can quickly have a running project, and I've used it a few times for Ludum Dares. But while the engine's code is well written and legible, it feels ancient. I wanted to dust it off to make use of more modern Javascript's features, like npm packages and ES6 modules.

In this post (and the followings), I will explain how ImpactJS works, and what steps I took to rise it to modern JS quality levels.

Disclaimer: because ImpactJS source code is not free (both meanings), I can only show code that is outside the scope of the engine itself.


Part 1 - The modules


Here is how an ImpactJS module looks like:

ig.module( 
    'game.main' 
)
.requires(
    'impact.game',
    'impact.font'
)
.defines(function(){

    MyGame = ig.Game.extend({
        font: new ig.Font( 'media/font.png' ),

        init: function() {},

        update: function() {
            this.parent();
        },

        draw: function() {
            this.parent();
            this.font.draw( 'Hello World', 0, 0, ig.Font.ALIGN.CENTER );
        }
    });

    ig.main( '#canvas', MyGame, 60, 320, 240, 2 );
});

It's pretty straightforward:
ig.module() defines the module name, which must match its path and filename.
.requires() makes sure that the listed modules are correctly loaded before the current one.
.defines() contains the code that will be executed, once the module is loaded.

You can see that the class MyGame is globally declared, because Impact's modules do not export data. Thus, all classes/variables must either be globally declared, or added as attributes of a global object (like ig).

How does it work under the hood? Pretty simply. When the game is loaded in dev mode, ImpactJS appends a <script> tag for each module called in requires(). Those modules are then executed by the browser, have their own requires() and so on. Once all the dependencies have been recursively added, the game can start. If the scope of your game is modest, this method is fast and convenient enough. When you build the game for distribution, all modules are concatenated in order and minified.

Now, how to improve those modules?

As my short-term goal is to make Impact ES6-compatible, I've easily replaced the old syntax with import and export statements without changing too much code. The engine's code itself is still riddled of globals that can be cleaned later, but the code I'll write for my game can be much more ES6 friendly.

The game.main that I showed above now looks like this:

import {ig} from '../impact/ig.js';
import {Game} from '../impact/game.js';
import {Font} from '../impact/font.js';

let MyGame = Game.extend({
  font: new Font('media/font.png'),

  init: function () {},

  update: function () {
    this.parent();
  },

  draw: function () {
    this.parent();
    this.font.draw('Hello World', 0, 0);
  },
});

ig.main('#canvas', MyGame, 60, 320, 240, 2);

It works as good as before, the code is already cleaner, and my IDE autocompletion is smarter.

Best of all, as evergreen browsers support ES6 modules, I don't even need a build step during development. Or do I?

Stay tuned for our next episode, "Part 2 - Time for a Brunch!"

entry.title: Make a Sign In Form With Unity and NodeJS

link.title: Make a Sign In Form With Unity and NodeJS

entry.content:
Ever dreamed of making your own login form in Unity, to authenticate your users through NodeJS? Good, that's exactly what we're about to do.

This post is not aimed at beginners, but will give you all the necessary code to make it work yourself. I recommend to have at least some familiarity with the following technologies:

  • Unity 5.4+, to use the UnityWebRequest class
  • NodeJS 8, ExpressJS and PassportJS
  • TypeScript. Not essential, but my backend code is written in it

For most of the Unity webcalls code, I used this blog post as a reference. You should read it too.

The NodeJS Server

Once the basic structure of your backend is written (hint: use express-generator), you'll have to implement PassportJS to authenticate your users. If you're not familiar with this library, the description on the official website says it all:

Passport is authentication middleware for Node.js. Extremely flexible and modular, Passport can be unobtrusively dropped in to any Express-based web application. A comprehensive set of strategies support authentication using a username and password, Facebook, Twitter, and more.

There are many plugins to easily implement strategies for Google, Facebook, tokens, etc. For this blog post, we'll roll our own local strategy to go straight to the point.

So, npm i passport passport-local, and let's write our passport config file.

passport.ts

passport.use(new LocalStrategy(
  {usernameField: 'email', passwordField: 'password'},
  async (email: string, password: string, done: any) => {
    try {
      // Fetch user from email
      const user = await User.findOne({email: email}).select('+password')

      // Check values and password
      if (user && user.password) {
        if (!await Auth.checkPassword(password, user.password)) {
          debug('Wrong password')
          return done(null, false, {message: 'Unknown user or incorrect password'})
        }
      }
      debug('Good password')
      return done(null, user)
    }
    catch (e) {
      console.error('PASSPORT ERROR')
      console.error(e)
      return done(null, false, {message: "Could not log in, please try again later"})
    }
  }))

Basically, we fetch the User from its email, check if the password — hashed with bcrypt — matches, and call the done callback.

Now, let's write the login/logout routes.

routes/index.ts

router.post('/login',
  passport.authenticate('local'),
  function (req: Request, res: Response) {
    return res.json(req.user)
  });

router.post('/logout', Auth.isLogged, (req: Request, res: Response) => {
  req.logout()
  return res.sendStatus(200)
})

Note: the middleware Auth.isLogged contains this simple code:

static isLogged(req: Request, res: Response, next: NextFunction) {
  if (req.user) {
    return next()
  }
  return res.sendStatus(401)
}

And just to check easily if we're logged, we'll add a /users/me call that will return the currently logged user.

routes/users.ts

router.get('/me', Auth.isLogged, async (req:Request, res:Response) => {
  let user = await User.findById(req.user._id)
  return res.json(user)
})

We now have everything needed for the backend side.

The Unity Client

Helpers

I created a few utility methods to simplify the multiple webcalls we'll have to write. We'll also take care of the cookie sent back by the server, as Unity won't do it for us.

Webservices.cs

static string baseURL = "http://localhost:3000";

public static string CookieString
{
    get {
        return PlayerPrefs.GetString("cookie");
    }
    set {
        PlayerPrefs.SetString("cookie", value);
    }
}

public static string BuildUrl(string path)
{
    return Path.Combine(baseURL, path).Replace(Path.DirectorySeparatorChar, '/');
}

public static UnityWebRequest Get(string path)
{
    var request = new UnityWebRequest(BuildUrl(path), "GET");
    if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(CookieString))
    {
        request.SetRequestHeader("cookie", CookieString);
    }
    request.downloadHandler = (DownloadHandler)new DownloadHandlerBuffer();
    request.SetRequestHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");
    return request;
}

public static UnityWebRequest Post(string path, string jsonString)
{
    var request = new UnityWebRequest(BuildUrl(path), "POST");
    if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(CookieString))
    {
        request.SetRequestHeader("cookie", CookieString);
    }
    byte[] bodyRaw = new System.Text.UTF8Encoding().GetBytes(jsonString);
    request.uploadHandler = (UploadHandler)new UploadHandlerRaw(bodyRaw);
    request.downloadHandler = (DownloadHandler)new DownloadHandlerBuffer();
    request.SetRequestHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");
    return request;
}

Those Get() and Post() methods will form the basis of our future calls. We're setting up the request instance with some handlers to consume the data once the server responds. We also inject the cookie string (if set), so that we keep our session throughout calls.

Now that those essential helpers are defined, we can focus on...

The form

Create your scene, and draw your UI to look like that:

Make your Login button trigger the LoginUser() method below, and link those two InputFields to the tfLogin and tfPassword attributes of the following script:

Login.cs

public class Login : MonoBehaviour {

    public InputField tfLogin, tfPassword;

    // Use this for initialization
    void Start () {

    }

    // Update is called once per frame
    void Update () {

    }

    public void LoginUser()
    {
        if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(tfLogin.text) && !string.IsNullOrEmpty(tfPassword.text))
        {
            StartCoroutine(SendLoginData());
        }
    }

    private IEnumerator SendLoginData()
    {
        var user = new User
        {
            email = tfLogin.text,
            password = tfPassword.text
        };
        // Delete cookie before requesting a new login
        Webservices.CookieString = null;

        var request = Webservices.Post("login", JsonUtility.ToJson(user));
        yield return request.Send();

        if (request.isNetworkError)
        {
            Debug.LogError(request.error);
        }
        else
        {
            Webservices.CookieString = request.GetResponseHeader("set-cookie");
            Debug.Log(Webservices.CookieString);
            Debug.Log(request.downloadHandler.text);
        }
    }
}

Aaaaand... it works. You should see the user data in place of the "[empty]" label right after clicking the button.

entry.title: Writing TypeScript for the TIC-80
entry.content:
The TIC-80 is a fantasy console (much like the well-known PICO-8, but with less restrictions) that suddenly became a lot more interesting to me with its last update, that allows developers to write games in JavaScript.

2017-08-05 Update: I transformed this into a real project, available from npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/tic80-typescript

Original post:

I'm not too fond of Lua — or dynamically typed languages in general, with the exception of JS — for various reasons, so the possibility of using JavaScript is a big deal for me, because it means that I can use TypeScript!

So, I created a small repository to host all the files needed to efficiently use TypeScript with TIC-80. It contains a definitions file with all the TIC-80 global functions, and a script that will compress the compiled JavaScript file, to save the maximum number of characters (as TIC-80 allows a maximum of 65535 bytes for the code). By default, the compressed file is still legible to ease the debugging, but you can save up to 60% of code, once compressed and mangled. It will be a bit harder to debug though.

You can read more about this project and download it here
